<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>27</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=28,EFW="2104057",CP="SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=14383,FOLIO='27',FILE='DISK025:[03WDC2.03WDC1152]DK1152A.;10',USER='WAVILES',CD='28-FEB-2003;10:30' -->
<!-- THIS IS THE END OF A COMPOSITION COMPONENT -->

<P><FONT SIZE=2><A
NAME="page_dm1152_1_28"> </A> </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><B><U>Results of Operations</U>  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Years Ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 and 2001  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net loss available to shareholders for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was $574.8&nbsp;million or net loss of $6.74 per share compared to net loss of
$138.1&nbsp;million or loss of $1.64 per share for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. The net loss for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 was largely the result of the cumulative effect
of change in accounting principle of $566.4&nbsp;million net of taxes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
broadcast revenues increased to $670.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $623.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, or 7.5%. The
year ending December&nbsp;31, 2002 was positively impacted by higher advertising revenues generated from the political, automotive, services, restaurants, home products, schools, and beer/wine,
offset by weakness in the fast food and soft drink sectors. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, national revenues increased to $271.9&nbsp;million, or 7.0%, from $254.0&nbsp;million
during 2001. National political revenues increased $19.1&nbsp;million, or 1,888.0%. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, local revenues increased to $369.0&nbsp;million, or 8.3%, from
$340.6&nbsp;million during 2001. Local political revenues increased $6.9&nbsp;million, or 556.0%, representing 2.0% of the increase in total local revenues. The increase in political revenues was
primarily the result of the several primary and general elections during 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;National
revenues, excluding political revenues, declined $1.3&nbsp;million to $251.7&nbsp;million, or 0.5%, during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $253.0&nbsp;million
during the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. Local revenues, excluding political revenues, increased $21.5&nbsp;million to $360.8&nbsp;million, or 6.3%, during the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $339.3&nbsp;million during 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Same
station basis is a comparison of only the stations that we owned or provided programming and operating services pursuant to an LMA for both entire years ending December&nbsp;31,
2002 and 2001. On a same station basis for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, national revenues including political revenues increased $17.2&nbsp;million, or 6.8%, and local sales increased
$29.4&nbsp;million, or 8.8%, over 2001. The increase in national revenues was primarily due to the increase in political revenues. The increase in
local revenues is related to our continued focus on developing a strong local sales force at each of our stations. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
addition, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, the events of September&nbsp;11<SUP>th</SUP> had a direct impact on the revenues of media related businesses. The impact of
the terrorist attacks to us due to pre-emptions and cancelled advertisements was estimated to be a $5.4&nbsp;million revenue loss during 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
network affiliations that experienced the largest revenue growth for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 were our NBC and CBS affiliates which increased 21.3% and 19.3%,
respectively, compared with the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. Our ABC and FOX affiliates experienced revenue growth of 11.3% and 9.1%, respectively, for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002
as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. The WB affiliates' revenue increased 2.0% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001.
The UPN affiliates' revenue decreased 1.7% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
revenue decreased to $4.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $6.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 or 37.7%. The decrease in
revenue relates to a decreased demand for services from our software development and consulting company, due to the slow economy and a decrease in revenue of $0.4&nbsp;million related to the closing
of the San Francisco office during the first quarter 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
costs were $309.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 compared to $311.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, a decrease of
$2.2&nbsp;million or 0.7%. The decrease in operating costs related to a decrease in program and production expenses due to the acquisition of </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>28</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=29,EFW="2104057",CP="SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=361703,FOLIO='28',FILE='DISK025:[03WDC2.03WDC1152]DM1152A.;10',USER='WAVILES',CD='28-FEB-2003;09:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1152_1_29"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
15 television broadcast licenses during the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2002, which we are able to operate at a lower cost than under the previous LMA structure. In addition, we reduced our
spending for the February rating sweeps promotion due to direct competition from the Olympics. The decrease in operating expenses also resulted from the full quarter effect of our restructuring
program initiated during the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2001, and the restructuring costs incurred during 2001, related to discontinued programming of local news at our stations
KDNL-TV in St. Louis, Missouri and WXLV-TV in Winston-Salem, North Carolina. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation
and amortization decreased $74.6&nbsp;million to $185.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $260.5&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001. The decrease in depreciation and amortization for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 was related to the adoption
of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 which resulted in the discontinuation of amortization of our goodwill and broadcast licenses, offset by an increase in amortization of our program contract costs and net
realizable value adjustments related to our addition of new programming such as Dharma&nbsp;&amp; Greg and Will&nbsp;&amp; Grace as well as write downs related to additional seasons for Frasier, Drew
Carey, Spin City, Just Shoot Me, and Third Rock from the Sun and an increase in depreciation of fixed assets related to our property additions, primarily resulting from our digital television
conversion. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, we did not incur any restructuring charges, impairment and write-down of long-lived assets (except for the impact of
adopting SFAS No.&nbsp;142) or contract termination costs. During the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2001, we offered a voluntary early retirement program to our eligible employees and
implemented a restructuring program to reduce operating and overhead costs. As a result, we reduced our staff by 186 employees and incurred a restructuring charge of $2.3&nbsp;million, which is
included in the accompanying consolidated statements of operations. During September&nbsp;2001, our station KDNL-TV in St. Louis, Missouri, discontinued programming its local news
broadcast. As a result, we incurred a restructuring charge of $1.1&nbsp;million. During December&nbsp;2001, WXLV-TV in Winston-Salem, North Carolina discontinued programming its local
news broadcast. As a result we incurred a restructuring charge of $0.3&nbsp;million. The restructuring charges related to severance and operating contract termination costs. During the nine months
ended September&nbsp;2001, we incurred an impairment and write-down of long-lived assets of $5.5&nbsp;million and contract termination costs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
income increased $146.6&nbsp;million to $184.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $38.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2001, or 385.8%. The net increase in operating income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 was primarily attributable to a decrease in
amortization due to the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 which resulted in the discontinuation of amortization of our goodwill and FCC licenses offset by an increase in program contract amortization
expense and property and equipment depreciation expense. Operating income was also affected by a decrease in program and production expenses due to the acquisition of 15 television broadcast licenses
resulting in our ability to operate at a cost lower than operating those stations as LMA structures and reduced spending for sweeps promotion due to direct competition from the Olympics. During the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, we incurred a loss of $16.1&nbsp;million related to a write down charge of long-lived assets. This charge is comprised of goodwill related to our
software development company and our station KBSI-TV in Paducah, Kentucky, and a write off of fixed assets which represent the net book value of damaged, obsolete or abandoned property. We
also incurred contract termination costs of $5.1&nbsp;million and restructuring charges of $3.7&nbsp;million during the year ended December&nbsp;2001. We did not incur any write-down
charge of long-lived assets, contract termination or restructuring charges for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
expense decreased to $126.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $143.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, or 11.9%. The
decrease in interest expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 resulted from the refinancing of indebtedness at lower interest rates </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>29</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=30,EFW="2104057",CP="SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=604319,FOLIO='29',FILE='DISK025:[03WDC2.03WDC1152]DM1152A.;10',USER='WAVILES',CD='28-FEB-2003;09:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1152_1_30"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
during December&nbsp;2001, March&nbsp;2002, July&nbsp;2002, November&nbsp;2002 and December&nbsp;2002 and an overall lower interest rate environment. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
income tax provision was $1.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 compared to an income tax benefit of $51.9&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001. Our tax rate changed to a provision in 2002 from a benefit in 2001 because we reported net income in 2002 compared to a net loss in 2001. The effective tax rate from
continuing operations decreased to 26.2% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from 31.3% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. The decrease is primarily because (prior to the
implementation of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 for 2002) our reported income in 2001 was reduced by amortization of goodwill, which was non-deductible for tax purposes. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Loss
related to investments decreased to $1.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to $7.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001.
The loss related to investments for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 primarily relates to a loss of $1.4&nbsp;million as a result of a write down of our investment in Allegiance Capital, a
loss of $0.1&nbsp;million from the sale of our interest in Synergy Brands,&nbsp;Inc., offset by a gain of $0.3&nbsp;million related to proceeds of a settlement to shareholders of Acrodyne. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
recognized income from discontinued operations of $7.9&nbsp;million, which includes a gain on the sale of WTTV-TV in Indianapolis, Indiana of $7.5&nbsp;million for the
year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to a loss from discontinued operations of $52,000 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
a result of the implementation of SFAS No.&nbsp;133, one of our derivatives does not qualify for special hedge accounting treatment. Therefore, this derivative must be recognized in
the balance sheet at fair market value and the changes in fair market value are reflected in earnings. As a result, we recognized $30.9&nbsp;million of losses during 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Broadcast
cash flow increased to $293.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $255.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, or 14.9%. The
broadcast cash flow margin for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 increased to 43.8% from 41.0% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. The increase in broadcast cash flow for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 was primarily due to an increase in net broadcast revenue, a decrease in operating costs, offset by an increase in
program contract payments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Adjusted
EBITDA increased to $273.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $235.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 or 16.1%. Adjusted
EBITDA margin increased to 40.8% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from 37.8% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. The increases in Adjusted EBITDA and margins for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 primarily resulted from an increase in net broadcast revenue and a decrease in operating costs offset by an increase in
program contract payments. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;After
tax cash flow increased to $143.7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $91.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, or 57.4%. The
increase in after tax cash flow for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, primarily resulted from an increase in net broadcast revenue, a
decrease in operating costs, a decrease in interest expense, an increase in the current tax benefit offset by an increase in program contract amortization. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Years ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 and 2000  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net loss available to common shareholders for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 was $138.1&nbsp;million or $1.64 per share compared to net income
available to common stockholders for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000 of $67.0&nbsp;million or $0.73 per share. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
broadcast revenue decreased $75.6&nbsp;million to $623.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 from $699.4&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2000, or 10.8%. The decrease in net </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>30</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=31,EFW="2104057",CP="SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=1001604,FOLIO='30',FILE='DISK025:[03WDC2.03WDC1152]DM1152A.;10',USER='WAVILES',CD='28-FEB-2003;09:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1152_1_31"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
broadcast revenue for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000 was comprised of a decrease in revenues of $84.1&nbsp;million on a same station
basis offset by an increase of $8.5&nbsp;million related to 2000 acquisitions, and the 2001 outsourcing agreement with WTXL-TV. On a same station basis, local revenue decreased
$23.0&nbsp;million and national revenue decreased $63.6&nbsp;million, offset by an increase in other broadcast revenue of $4.0&nbsp;million. Other broadcast revenue increased by
$2.5&nbsp;million related to an increase in tower rental revenue and an increase in syndicator revenue. Political revenues declined $23.7&nbsp;million to $2.3&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2001 compared to $26.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;30, 2000, or 91.2%, representing 1.5% of the decrease in local revenues and 4.6% of the decrease in
national revenues. The decrease in political revenues was primarily the result of the Presidential election and numerous local elections during the 2000 period. The decrease in national and local
revenues was primarily due to a soft advertising market resulting from a weak economy as well as increasing competition from other forms of advertising-based mediums, particularly network, cable
television, direct satellite television, and Internet that have a direct impact on the distribution of advertising dollars in our markets. In addition, the events of September&nbsp;11, 2001 had a
direct impact on the revenues of media related businesses. The terrorist attacks led to the pre-emption and cancellation of advertisements, which caused a $5.4&nbsp;million revenue loss
during 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
revenue increased $2.4&nbsp;million to $6.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 from $4.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000, or
53.3%. The increase was comprised of a general increase in Internet consulting and development revenue generated by G1440, which represents sales of $1.9&nbsp;million and an increase in sales of
$1.5&nbsp;million due to the 2000 acquisition of a software design company, an increase in sales related to the "Builder" software product division offset by a decrease of $1.2&nbsp;million
related to the reorganization of the San Francisco office of G1440. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total
operating costs decreased $9.3&nbsp;million to $311.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 from $320.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2000, or 2.9%. The decrease in operating costs for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000 was comprised of a decrease in programming and
production expense of $6.4&nbsp;million and a decrease in selling, general and administrative costs of $3.0&nbsp;million. The decrease in selling, general and administrative costs related to an
increase of $1.9&nbsp;million in general and administrative costs for G1440, $0.7&nbsp;million for health insurance, and $0.9&nbsp;million in bad debt, offset by a decrease in sales expense of
$4.2&nbsp;million, and a decrease in salaries of $2.5&nbsp;million. On a same station basis, operating costs decreased by $10.5&nbsp;million offset by an increase of $5.7&nbsp;million related
to 2000 acquisitions and our outsourcing agreement with WTXL-TV. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Depreciation
and amortization increased $29.6&nbsp;million to $260.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 from $230.9&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2000. The increase in depreciation and amortization related to fixed asset, intangible asset, and program contract additions associated with the 2000 acquisitions and program
contract additions related to our investment in programming. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
expense decreased $8.6&nbsp;million to $143.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 from $152.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2000, or 5.7%. The decrease in interest expense for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000 primarily resulted from the reduction of our
indebtedness using the proceeds from the disposition of our radio broadcast assets in December&nbsp;2000 and, during 2001, an overall lower interest rate market environment, offset by an increase in
interest expense related to capital leases. Subsidiary trust minority interest expense of $23.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 is related to the private placement of the
$200&nbsp;million aggregate liquidation value 11.625% high yield trust offered preferred securities (HYTOPS) completed March&nbsp;12, 1997. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>31</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=32,EFW="2104057",CP="SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=776290,FOLIO='31',FILE='DISK025:[03WDC2.03WDC1152]DM1152A.;10',USER='WAVILES',CD='28-FEB-2003;09:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1152_1_32"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Operating
income decreased $117.9&nbsp;million to $38.0&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 from $155.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2000. The net decrease in operating income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000 was primarily attributable to a decrease in net broadcast
revenues, an increase in depreciation and amortization, an impairment and write down charge of $16.1&nbsp;million, a restructuring charge of $2.3&nbsp;million related to a reduction in our work
force of 186 employees and a restructuring charge of $1.4&nbsp;million related to the discontinuance of the news at our stations KDNL-TV, St. Louis, Missouri and WXLV-TV in
Winston-Salem, North Carolina, and contract termination costs. These costs were offset by decreases in programming production costs as well as selling, general and administrative costs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
June&nbsp;2001, the San Francisco office of our Internet consulting and development subsidiary was reorganized. The office reduced staff due to a significant slow down of
business activity in the San Francisco market. In addition, the focus of the San Francisco office has shifted toward marketing an existing product. As a result, management determined that the San
Francisco office's goodwill was permanently impaired and, as such, recorded a charge to write-off goodwill in the amount of $2.8&nbsp;million during June&nbsp;2001. Also, during 2001,
we wrote-off $4.2&nbsp;million of fixed assets which represents the net book value of damaged, obsolete, or abandoned property. The impairment and write-down charge decreased
operating income as noted above. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
February&nbsp;2001, we offered a voluntary early retirement program to eligible employees and implemented a restructuring program to reduce operating and overhead costs. As a
result, we reduced our staff by 186 employees and incurred a restructuring charge of $2.3&nbsp;million which is included in the accompanying Consolidated Statements of Operations. During
September&nbsp;2001, KDNL-TV in St. Louis, Missouri discontinued programming its local news broadcast. As a result, we incurred a restructuring charge of $1.1&nbsp;million. During
December&nbsp;2001, WXLV-TV in Winston-Salem, North Carolina
discontinued programming its local news broadcast. As a result, we incurred a restructuring charge of $0.3&nbsp;million. The restructuring charges related to severance, operating contract
termination costs, and legal costs. The restructuring charge decreased operating income for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the third quarter of 2001, Sinclair terminated certain agreements and entered into new agreements with unrelated third parties. We incurred $5.1&nbsp;million of contract
termination costs, and we received $21.4&nbsp;million for entering into a new contract. Both the amounts will be recognized as a reduction of selling, general and administrative expenses on a
straight-line basis over the term of the contracts. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Loss
related to investments decreased to $7.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 as compared to $16.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000.
The loss related to investments for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 primarily relates to a loss of $4.2&nbsp;million recognized during 2001 as a result of our write-off of our
loans to Acrodyne Communications,&nbsp;Inc. (Acrodyne), of which, as of December&nbsp;31, 2001, we held approximately a 35% equity interest. We also recognized losses as a result of write-downs of
our investments for How Stuff Works,&nbsp;Inc. of $0.9&nbsp;million, Chatfish of $0.6&nbsp;million and Synergy Brands,&nbsp;Inc. of $2.1&nbsp;million. Our equity earnings for our investment
in Allegiance Capital L.P. increased by $0.2&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
recognized a loss from discontinued operations of $52,000 for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 as compared to $6.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000.
The loss from discontinued operations for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 related to the sale of WTTV-TV in Indianapolis, Indiana. Of the net income from discontinued operations,
net of taxes for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000, $2.0&nbsp;million related to the sale of WTTV-TV, Indianapolis, Indiana and $4.9&nbsp;million resulted from the disposition of
our radio broadcast assets in December&nbsp;1999 and during 2000. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>32</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=33,EFW="2104057",CP="SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=389819,FOLIO='32',FILE='DISK025:[03WDC2.03WDC1152]DM1152A.;10',USER='WAVILES',CD='28-FEB-2003;09:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1152_1_33"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
a result of the implementation of SFAS No.&nbsp;133, one of our derivatives does not qualify for special hedge accounting treatment. Therefore, this derivative must be recognized in
the balance sheet at fair market value and the changes in fair market value are reflected in earnings. As a result, we recognized $32.2&nbsp;million of losses during 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Broadcast
cash flow decreased $74.4&nbsp;million to $255.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 from $329.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2000, or 22.6%. The broadcast cash flow margin for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 decreased to 41.0% from 45.1% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000. The decrease in broadcast cash
flow and margins for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000 was comprised of an $78.0&nbsp;million, or 23.6%, decrease in broadcast cash flow on
a same station basis, offset by an increase of $1.6&nbsp;million related to the 2000 acquisitions and a decrease in operating expenses. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Adjusted
EBITDA represents broadcast cash flow less corporate expenses. Adjusted EBITDA decreased $71.8&nbsp;million to $235.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2001 from $307.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000, or 23.3%. Adjusted EBITDA margin decreased to 37.8% for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 from 41.9% for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2000. The decrease in adjusted EBITDA and margins for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000 resulted primarily from
the circumstances affecting broadcast cash flow margins as noted above combined with a $2.6&nbsp;million decrease in corporate expenses. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;After
tax cash flow decreased $54.2&nbsp;million to $91.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 from $145.5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2000, or 37.3%. The decrease in after tax cash flow for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 as compared to the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2000 primarily resulted from a decrease in net
broadcast revenues, offset by an increase in current tax benefit and a decrease in interest expense. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Recent Accounting Pronouncements  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In June&nbsp;2001, the Financial Accounting Standards Board (FASB), approved Statement of Financial Accounting Standard (SFAS) No.&nbsp;141, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Business
Combinations</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, and SFAS No.&nbsp;142, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Goodwill and Other Intangible Assets</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. SFAS
No.&nbsp;141 prospectively prohibits the pooling of interest method of accounting for business combinations initiated after June&nbsp;30, 2001. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 requires companies to cease
amortizing goodwill and certain other intangible assets including broadcast licenses effective January&nbsp;1, 2002. SFAS No.&nbsp;142 also establishes a new method of testing goodwill and
broadcast licenses for impairment on an annual basis or on an interim basis if an event occurs or circumstances change that would reduce the fair value of a reporting unit below its carrying value.
The adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 resulted in discontinuation of amortization of our goodwill and broadcast licenses effective January&nbsp;1, 2002; however, we were required to test goodwill and
broadcast licenses for impairment under the new standard during 2002. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;During
the three months ended March&nbsp;31, 2002, we tested our broadcast licenses for impairment in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;142 based on the estimated fair value of such
licenses in their respective markets. We estimated the fair values of our broadcast licenses using discontinued cash flow models. The estimated fair value was compared to the book value to determine
whether any impairment had occurred. As a result of this analysis we incurred a pretax impairment charge of $64.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SFAS
No.&nbsp;142 requires that goodwill be tested for impairment at the reporting unit level at adoption and at least annually thereafter, utilizing a two-step
methodology. The initial step required us to determine the fair value of each reporting unit and compare it to the carrying value, including goodwill, of such unit. If the fair value exceeded the
carrying value, no impairment loss was recognized. However, if the carrying value of the reporting unit exceeded its fair value, the goodwill of this unit might have been impaired. The amount, if any,
of the impairment would then be measured in the second step. The second step requires us to calculate the fair value of goodwill by allocating the fair </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>33</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=34,EFW="2104057",CP="SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=339540,FOLIO='33',FILE='DISK025:[03WDC2.03WDC1152]DM1152A.;10',USER='WAVILES',CD='28-FEB-2003;09:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1152_1_34"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
value of the reporting unit to each of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit based on their fair values. This calculated goodwill is then compared to the book value of the goodwill and an
impairment loss is recognized to the extent that the book value exceeds the fair value. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
determined that our designated marketing areas (DMAs) were reporting units under SFAS&nbsp;142. In connection with adopting this standard during 2002, we completed step one of the
test for impairment by comparing the book value of our reporting units, including goodwill, to the estimated fair value of our reporting units as of January&nbsp;1, 2002. We estimated the fair value
of our reporting units using a combination of quoted market prices, observed earnings multiples paid for comparable television stations and discounted cash flow models. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
performed the second step of the goodwill impairment test for those DMAs whose goodwill was found to be potentially impaired as a result of the first step. We performed the second
step by allocating the estimated fair value of the reporting unit to each of the assets and liabilities of the reporting unit based on their estimated fair values. We estimated the fair values of the
assets and liabilities using a combination of observed prices paid for similar assets and liabilities, discounted cash flow models and appraisals. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
a result of such testing, we recorded a pre-tax impairment charge of $532.8&nbsp;million related to nine of our DMAs and our software development and consulting company.
The total impairment charge of $596.8&nbsp;million related to our broadcast licenses and goodwill is reflected as a cumulative effect of a change in accounting principle on our consolidated
statement of operations, net of the related tax benefit of $30.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SFAS&nbsp;142
requires goodwill and definite lived intangible assets to be tested for impairment on an annual basis; therefore, we tested these assets for impairment as of
October&nbsp;1, 2002 by comparing their book values to their estimated fair values. There was no impairment charge recorded based on the results of such testing. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SFAS
No.&nbsp;133, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, as amended by SFAS No.&nbsp;137, </FONT> <FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging
Activities&#151;Deferral of the Effective Date of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;133,</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> and SFAS
No.&nbsp;138</FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>, Accounting for Derivative Instruments and Hedging Activities</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> requires that an entity recognize all derivative instruments and hedging
activities as either assets or liabilities on the balance sheet measured at their fair values. Changes in fair value of all derivative instruments and hedging activities are required to be recognized
through earnings unless specific hedge accounting criteria are met. We adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;133 as of January&nbsp;1, 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June&nbsp;2001, the FASB approved SFAS No.&nbsp;143, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Asset Retirement Obligations</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. SFAS No.&nbsp;143 is effective
for fiscal years beginning after June&nbsp;15, 2002 and addresses financial accounting and
reporting for obligations associated with the retirement of tangible long-lived assets and the associated asset retirement costs. We do not expect the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;143 to
have a material effect on our financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;144, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> on January&nbsp;1, 2002. As a
result of adopting SFAS No.&nbsp;144, we classified the assets and liabilities of WTTV-TV as assets and liabilities held for sale on the balance sheet and reported the results of
operations of WTTV-TV as discontinued operations on the accompanying statements of operations. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
April of 2002, the FASB approved SFAS No.&nbsp;145, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Rescission of FASB Statements No.&nbsp;4, 44 and 64, Amendment of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;13 and
Technical Corrections</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. SFAS No.&nbsp;145 will require us to record gains and losses on extinguishment of debt as a component of income from continuing operations rather than
as an extraordinary item and to reclassify such items for all periods presented. We adopted this provision of SFAS No.&nbsp;145 on January&nbsp;1, 2003. We do not expect the other provisions of
SFAS No.&nbsp;145 to have a material effect on our consolidated financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>34</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=35,EFW="2104057",CP="SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=400950,FOLIO='34',FILE='DISK025:[03WDC2.03WDC1152]DM1152A.;10',USER='WAVILES',CD='28-FEB-2003;09:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1152_1_35"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
June&nbsp;2002, the FASB approved SFAS No.&nbsp;146, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Costs Associated with Exit or Disposal Activities</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>. SFAS
No.&nbsp;146 is effective after December&nbsp;31, 2002, and addresses financial accounting and reporting for costs associated with exit or disposal activities and nullifies EITF issue
No.&nbsp;94-3, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Liability Recognition for Certain Employee Termination Benefits and Other Costs to Exit an Activity.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> The primary difference
between SFAS No.&nbsp;146 and EITF 94-3 concerns the timing of liability recognition and we do not expect the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;146 to have material effect on our consolidated
financial statements. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
November&nbsp;2002, the Emerging Issues Task Forces (EITF) reached a concensus on Issue 02-16, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting by Reseller for Cash Consideration
Received from a Vendor</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2>, (EITF 02-16). EITF 02-16 requires us to treat our deferred commission credits as a reduction in selling expense when realized
and not as broadcast revenue. We adopted EITF 02-16 on December&nbsp;31, 2002. This adoption resulted in a reclassification of $3.9&nbsp;million and $1.6&nbsp;million for the years
ended December&nbsp;2002 and 2001, respectively. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;2002, we adopted SFAS No.&nbsp;148, </FONT><FONT SIZE=2><I>Accounting for Stock-Based Compensation-Transaction and Disclosure, an Amendment of FASB
No.&nbsp;123.</I></FONT><FONT SIZE=2> SFAS No.&nbsp;148 revises the methods permitted by SFAS No.&nbsp;123 of measuring compensation expense for stock-based employee compensation plans. We use
the intrinsic value method prescribed in Accounting Principles Board Option No.&nbsp;25, as permitted under SFAS No.&nbsp;123. Therefore, this change did not have a material effect on our
financial statements. SFAS No.&nbsp;148 requires us to disclose pro forma information related to stock-based compensation, in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;123, on a quarterly basis in addition to
the current annual basis disclosure. We will report the pro forma information on an interim basis beginning with our March&nbsp;31, 2003 Form&nbsp;10-Q. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Liquidity and Capital Resources  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our primary source of liquidity is cash provided by operations and availability under our 2002 Bank Credit Agreement. As of December&nbsp;31, 2002, we had
$5.3&nbsp;million in cash balances and working capital of approximately $88.5&nbsp;million. We anticipate that cash flow from our operations and revolving credit facility will be sufficient to
satisfy our debt service obligations, dividend requirements, capital expenditure requirements and operating cash needs for the next year. There can be no assurance that we will be successful in
obtaining the required amount of funds for these items. As of February&nbsp;14, 2003, the remaining balance available under the revolving credit facility was $173.0&nbsp;million. Our ability to
draw down our line of credit is based on pro forma trailing cash flow levels and for the twelve months ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, we had approximately $173.0&nbsp;million available of current
borrowing capacity under our revolving credit facility. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
March&nbsp;2002, we completed an issuance of $300.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 8% Senior Subordinated Notes (the 2002 Notes), due 2012, generating net proceeds to
us of $297.3&nbsp;million. The gross proceeds of this offering were utilized to repay $300.0&nbsp;million of the Term Loan Facility under our 1998 Bank Credit Agreement. We recognized an
extraordinary loss of $0.7&nbsp;million, net of a tax benefit of $0.4&nbsp;million. The extraordinary loss represented a write-off of the deferred financing costs. Interest on the 2002
Notes is payable semiannually on March&nbsp;15th and September&nbsp;15th of each year beginning September&nbsp;15, 2002. The 2002 Notes were issued under an indenture among SBG, its subsidiaries
(the guarantors) and the trustee. Net costs associated with the offering totaled $3.4&nbsp;million. These costs were capitalized and are being amortized to interest expense over the term of the 2002
Notes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
July&nbsp;15, 2002, we closed on a new Bank Credit Agreement (the 2002 Bank Credit Agreement), allowing us more operating capacity and liquidity. The proceeds of the 2002 Bank
Credit Agreement were used to pay off the 1998 Bank Credit Agreement. The 2002 Bank Credit Agreement consists of a $225.0&nbsp;million Revolving Credit Facility maturing on June&nbsp;30, 2008 and
a $375.0&nbsp;million Term Loan B </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>35</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=8,SEQ=36,EFW="2104057",CP="SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=965864,FOLIO='35',FILE='DISK025:[03WDC2.03WDC1152]DM1152A.;10',USER='WAVILES',CD='28-FEB-2003;09:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1152_1_36"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
Facility repayable in consecutive quarterly installments, amortizing 0.25% per quarter, commencing June&nbsp;30, 2004 and continuing through its maturity on December&nbsp;31, 2009. The applicable
interest rate on the Revolving Credit Facility is either LIBOR plus 1.25% to 2.25% or the alternative base rate plus 0.25% to 1.25% adjusted quarterly based on the ratio of total debt, net of cash, to
four quarters' trailing earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, as adjusted in accordance with the 2002 Bank Credit Agreement. The applicable interest rate on the Term Loan B
Facility is either LIBOR plus 2.25% or the alternative base rate plus 1.25%. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
November&nbsp;8, 2002, the Company completed an add-on issuance of $125.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount to the 8% Senior Subordinated Notes due 2012 at a
premium of $0.6&nbsp;million generating net proceeds of $125.8&nbsp;million. We used the net proceeds together with available cash on hand and a draw down of $10.0&nbsp;million on the revolving
line of credit under the 2002 Bank Credit Agreement, to redeem our existing 9% Senior Subordinated Notes including an early redemption premium of $9.0&nbsp;million and accrued interest of
$7.2&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
December&nbsp;31, 2002, we completed an add-on issuance of $125.0&nbsp;million aggregate principal amount of 8% Senior Subordinated Notes due 2012 at a premium of
$3.8&nbsp;million. We received net proceeds of approximately $130.4&nbsp;million from the sale of the notes. We used the net proceeds together with additional funding from our term loan of
$125&nbsp;million, a draw down of $7.0&nbsp;million on the revolving line of credit under the 2002 Bank Credit Agreement and available cash on hand of $0.2&nbsp;million to redeem our existing
8.75% Senior Subordinated Notes due 2007, including an early redemption premium of $10.9&nbsp;million and costs associated with the offering totalling $1.7&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
April&nbsp;19, 2002, we filed a $350.0&nbsp;million universal shelf registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission which will permit us to offer and sell
various types of securities from time to time. Offered securities may include common stock, debt securities, preferred stock, depositary shares or any combination thereof in amounts, prices and on
terms to be announced when the securities are offered. If we determine it is in our best interest to offer any such securities, we intend to use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, including,
but not limited to, the reduction or refinancing of debt or other obligations, acquisitions, capital expenditures, and working capital. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
weighted average interest rates for outstanding indebtedness relating to our Bank Credit Agreement during 2001 and as of December&nbsp;31, 2001 were 6.57% and 5.85%, respectively.
The weighted average interest rates of our Bank Credit Agreement during 2002 and as of December&nbsp;31, 2002 were 5.14% and 4.12%, respectively. During 2002, the interest expense relating to the
Bank Credit Agreements was $27.9&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
cash flows from operating activities increased to $149.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $58.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
2001. We received income tax refunds net of payments of $44.1&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to income tax payments, net of refunds of $1.2&nbsp;million for
the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. We made interest payments on outstanding indebtedness and payments for subsidiary trust minority interest expense totaling $142.9&nbsp;million for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to $173.6&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. Program rights payments increased to $106.3&nbsp;million for the year ended
December&nbsp;31, 2002 from $102.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001 or 3.9%. This increase in program rights payments was comprised of $8.7&nbsp;million related to an
increase in programming costs on a same station basis, offset by a decrease in payments related to the disposition of WTTV-TV. This increase in program rights payments resulted from our
investment to upgrade our television programming. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
cash flows from investing activities were $52.8&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 as compared to net cash flows used in investing activity of
$33.3&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. This increase in net cash flows used in investing activity was primarily due to the sale of WTTV broadcast assets and repayments of
notes receivable, offset by payments relating to the </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>36</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=9,SEQ=37,EFW="2104057",CP="SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=307216,FOLIO='36',FILE='DISK025:[03WDC2.03WDC1152]DM1152A.;10',USER='WAVILES',CD='28-FEB-2003;09:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1152_1_37"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
acquisition of broadcast assets, property and equipment expenditures and equity investments. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, we received proceeds of $124.5&nbsp;million from the sale
of WTTV-TV, we
made cash payments of approximately $21.2&nbsp;million related to the acquisition of television broadcast assets and received cash proceeds of $0.7&nbsp;million related to the sale of broadcast
assets. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, we made equity investments of approximately $25.8&nbsp;million. During 2002, we made payments for property and equipment of
$62.9&nbsp;million of which $49.6&nbsp;million, related to digital conversion costs. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;For
2003, we anticipate to incur approximately $92.0&nbsp;million of capital expenditures, of which $50.0&nbsp;million relates to the completion of our digital television
roll-out, approximately $10.0&nbsp;million for improvements and $32.0 milllion for the news expansion program. In addition, we anticipate that future requirements for capital
expenditures will include capital expenditures incurred during the ordinary course of business and additional strategic station acquisitions and equity investments if suitable investments can be
identified on acceptable terms. We expect to fund such capital expenditures with cash generated from operating activities and funding from our Revolving Credit Facility. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net
cash flows used in financing activities decreased to $229.2&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from net cash flows from financing activities of
$2.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, we repaid $1.5&nbsp;billion under the Term Loan Facility and utilized borrowings
under the Revolving Credit Facility of $1.3&nbsp;billion. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, we received $21.8&nbsp;million related to the termination of two of our derivative
instruments. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, we repaid a net $229.5&nbsp;million of indebtedness, whereas in the comparable period in 2001, we borrowed a net $4.3&nbsp;million,
offset by repurchases of Class&nbsp;A common stock of $4.4&nbsp;million and payment of an equity put option premium of $7.7&nbsp;million during 2001. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
closed on the sale of four radio stations in Kansas City, Missouri in July&nbsp;2000 for a purchase price of $126.6&nbsp;million. In October&nbsp;2000, we closed on the sale of
our radio stations in the St. Louis market for a purchase price of $220.0&nbsp;million and on the purchase of the stock of Grant Television,&nbsp;Inc., including the non-license assets
of WNYO-TV in Buffalo, New York together with a $3.2&nbsp;million note receivable issued by Sinclair that holds the license assets, for a purchase price of $48.0&nbsp;million. In
November&nbsp;2000, we closed on the sale of our radio station in Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania for a purchase price of $0.6&nbsp;million. These transactions generated net after-tax
proceeds of approximately $229.0&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Income Taxes  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The income tax provision from continuing operations increased to $1.4&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from a benefit of
$51.9&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002, our pre-tax book income from continuing operations was $5.2&nbsp;million
and for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2001, our pre-tax book loss from continuing operations was $165.3&nbsp;million. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;As
of December&nbsp;31, 2002, we have a net deferred tax liability of $167.2&nbsp;million as compared to a net deferred tax liability of $155.5&nbsp;million as of
December&nbsp;31, 2001. The increase is primarily due to the adoption of SFAS No.&nbsp;142. Our tax rate changed to a provision in 2002 from a benefit in 2001 because
we reported net income in 2002 compared to a net loss in 2001. The effective tax rate from continuing operations decreased to 26.2% from the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2002 from 31.3% for the year
ended December&nbsp;31, 2001. The decrease is primarily because (prior to the implementation of SFAS No.&nbsp;142 for 2002) our reported income in 2001 was reduced by amortization of goodwill,
which was non-deductible for tax purposes. </FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
December&nbsp;2001, the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) completed its examination of our federal income tax returns filed through 1997. As a result of this settlement, our fiscal
year 2001 benefit for </FONT></P>

<P ALIGN="CENTER"><FONT SIZE=2>37</FONT></P>

<HR NOSHADE>
<!-- ZEQ.=10,SEQ=38,EFW="2104057",CP="SINCLAIR BROADCAST GROUP, INC.",DN="1",CHK=240922,FOLIO='37',FILE='DISK025:[03WDC2.03WDC1152]DM1152A.;10',USER='WAVILES',CD='28-FEB-2003;09:51' -->
<A NAME="page_dm1152_1_38"> </A>
<BR>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>
income taxes reflects a $6.3&nbsp;million reduction of taxes provided in prior periods. The IRS has initiated an examination of federal tax returns subsequent to 1998. We believe that adequate
accruals have been provided for all years. </FONT></P>


<P><FONT SIZE=2><B>Seasonality/Cyclicality  </B></FONT></P>

<P><FONT SIZE=2>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our results usually are subject to seasonal fluctuations, which usually cause fourth quarter operating income to be greater than first, second and third quarter
operating income. This seasonality is primarily attributable to increased expenditures by advertisers in anticipation of holiday season spending and an increase in viewership during this period. In
addition, revenues from political advertising and the Olympics are higher in even numbered years. </FONT></P>
